answers.author: Paul Scher
answers.text:
Thank you for this most interesting question. As you’ve noted in your question, most county or city code provisions regarding commercial and residential occupancy standards focus on room type and minimum square-footage per occupant. Occupancy standards must also fall in line with the requirements of the Fair Housing Act of 1968 (http://bit.ly/eSHYDQ) and the various regulatory handbooks (http://1.usa.gov/kVnBy6) issued by the Department of Housing and Urban Development. An excellent illustrated example of county-level regulations is Occupancy Standards in Montgomery County (http://bit.ly/lAgzIM), as presented by CASA DE MARYLAND. I was not able to find any information regarding non-room type or footage-based standards. Does anyone have any knowledge of such a regulatory scheme?

author: [Anonymous]
text: Does anyone have city- or county-wide adopted occupancy standards?   Are there any out there that are NOT based on room type and minimum square footages, that don't create potential fair housing issues?  If so, we would like to know how to get a copy.
title: Housing Occupancy Standards
